questions.question: What DMA component manages data transfers?
questions.explanation: DMA controllers handle transfers between devices and memory. They operate independently of the CPU.

questions.question: What uses separate address spaces for devices?
questions.explanation: Port-mapped I/O uses special instructions for device access. It separates I/O from memory address space.

questions.question: What channel handles one high-speed device?
questions.explanation: Selector channels dedicate themselves to single fast devices. They're used for disks and tapes.

questions.question: What RAID level provides mirroring?
questions.explanation: RAID 1 mirrors data across disks. It provides redundancy but doubles storage cost.

questions.question: What RAID level uses striping with parity?
questions.explanation: RAID 5 stripes data and distributes parity across disks. It balances performance and redundancy.

questions.question: What disk group shares the same cylinder?
questions.explanation: Cylinders are tracks at the same position on all platters. They can be read without head movement.

questions.question: What arranges data on disk for sequential access?
questions.explanation: Tracks are circular paths on disk platters. Each track holds many sectors.

questions.question: What reduces disk latency through caching?
questions.explanation: Disk caches store frequently accessed data in memory. They dramatically reduce access times.

questions.question: What operation flushes cached writes to disk?
questions.explanation: Sync operations force cached data to permanent storage. They ensure durability.

questions.question: What I/O mode allows process continuation before completion?
questions.explanation: Asynchronous I/O returns immediately, allowing concurrent work. Completion is signaled later.
